No issues on Linux. Pretty well optimised too – I got buttery smooth experience on PC with highest settings in 4K. It's a lot of fun with friends, and a decent bit of fun playing solo with bots, but a hit&miss when playing with strangers online. Voice chat works great. What I don't like in single player, is that at some point you need to re-play previous levels as every character, so that your bots had good enough gear and level / talents in order to beat more difficult missions. Versus mode is quite interesting, with two teams interchangably playing as heroes or vermin, but people get annoyed when you're just a beginner, so I recommend getting comfortable with legend difficulty in adventure mode first. A solid title. Even though I'm not a fan of Warhammer, I give Vermintide 2 easy 7/10.

I grabbed Warhammer Vermintide 2 for free on Steam, and honestly, it was a solid surprise. The game feels intense and chaotic in the best way, especially when you're fighting off huge swarms with friends. The combat has weight, the atmosphere is gritty, and it’s just satisfying to play. It does get a bit repetitive, but in a fun, addictive kind of way. For something I didn’t even pay for, it turned out way better than expected.

If you're a fan of games like Left of Dead, then Vermintide 2 is a great co-op experience if you got at least a couple of other friends to play it with. The gameplay is simple enough; you run around, swing your weapons, use your bows and magics, kill skaven (ratmen) and other horrors and monsters, have a simple goal to achieve at the end of each stage and just generally have a fun time being over-the-top badasses taking on literal armies on your own.

You get five classes to choose from. They themselves have subclasses, some of which change how you play the character by quite a bit. They complement each others strengths and weaknesses, though admittedly some subclasses in particular feel flat out stronger than other classes. And that's even after they've rolled out several nerfs. In co-op mode it's not an issue though, if anything it can be kinda fun just running overpowered characters and mowing down armies. There's several difficulty options, and on the highest difficulties things get pretty tough anyway even with the stronger characters, so there's a lot of challenge to be had if you desire. 

There's not all that much story to find other than loose dialogue inbetween and during missions, but the game doesn't really need that much story; the lands are being invaded by skaven and other forces, and it's your job to stop them. That's your story. It ties into a larger story within the Warhammer Fantasy universe, but it's not all that important to the game itself. Gameplay is king here, and the gameplay is fun as hell, if perhaps a bit repetetive if you don't enjoy swinging weapons around 24/7.

It's a good fun all around if you enjoy more straight forward action games that still have some depth to them if you get into it. If you enjoy co-op action games it's basically a must play. 

And it's from a developer that just keeps on giving. It's been out for seven years, eight years in march next year, and Fatshark has no obligation to keep supporting the game, release new content nor release patches and balance fixes. And yet they do. The game is still quite popular too, which I think says a lot about how fun it is. 

If you haven't already, you should get into it. You can usually get it, including all dlc, for cheap during holidays and Steam events. So there's not much reason not to give it a shot. 

If you have friends to play with, that is. It's not that fun on it's own as the AI isn't always the brightest. And playing with random players online can be a mixed bag of experiences to say the least.

Writing a review of the game to complete the SANC badge but also because I should have written one already.

Medieval L4D, with very frustrating rats that will follow you till the ends of times (unfortunately) and be your doom from Legend and beyond. You always think you're safe between waves, dodging everything and keeping your health intact just for you to have one of those furry little guys stab you in the back with a special hit. 

A ragebaiting game, with you getting bugged sometimes (at least it's good when it's the bosses), random players of low level hoping to be carried on Legend (very entertaining, though, always happy to help) but the whole team dying just at the end of the map. Also thinking you managed to block a hit only to get on the ground anyway, and occasionally getting kicked out of the matches for no reason.

Still, very enjoyable and with a very nice community. Before the game being free for that certain period of time, we were the same 30 rat lovers just switching lobbies, so I'm glad more people is playing it now. 
It has nice mechanics, different characters that adapt different types of players, and good enough optimization to run smoothly. 

You can always learn combos, builds, how to block, dodge and move through the map strategically, or just turn your brain off and be a Slayer. Being a maniac dwarf that jumps around and smashes rats after a long stressful day always helps. 

So yes, I do recommend this game. The routine is nice, the maps are entertaining, and in my own personal experience, some very, very special people that I've met through it has made it even more worth it than it was already. I will always be grateful for that serendipity. 11/10

Gameplay: 23/25 - Excellent fluid and dynamic gameplay, which, despite its horde-survival aggressive and brutal nature, requires strategy and patience at all levels. The 5 proposed characters, each tied to 4 specialization branches, are sufficiently diversified to provide gameplay interest and satisfaction. The banner of weapon choices, skill-tree, and possible combinations are nuanced enough to allow relevant and effective builds. Cooperative mechanics, like in most games of the genre, are respected through special units and bosses that bring difficulty and the necessary contrast to the monotony of the massacre, even if some of them can bring frustration due to their (too) discreet characteristics, notably the Life-Stealers who can summon tornadoes at long distances while hidden at the back of the group, or by their (too) dazzling characteristics (intentional or not), like the Rat-Gunner and the Warpfire Thrower. In conclusion, the ragdoll-type physics engine of the game is an integral and non-negligible variable of the final quality, which makes everything extremely enjoyable and unique, allowing to play for hours.

Immersion: 25/25 - A Warhammer universe faithful to what it is, thanks to lore characteristic of other games in the license but which does not fail to be developed and very deep. The immersion and details attributed to this universe are stunning, notably the VERY numerous dialogues between characters, all unique from each other, which tell the story of the universe, but also the dozens of proposed maps which do not fail to be exceptional and concretize the numerous fantastic images described in novels of the fictional genre, played by their color palettes and their epic gigantisms.

Design: 15/25 - Despite solid gameplay, immersion, and graphics, one cannot overlook the repetitiveness of objectives despite nice but small attempts on certain maps in normal mode (I think of Reikland where we fight on boats, mechanisms like the Screaming Bell chains or the line alignment at Athel Yenlui). The Power system of equipment, similar to gachas, is not clearly explained and creates frustration due to its completely random nature, making the acquisition of Exotique/Veteran equipment (the maximum ranks) not as jubilant as it should be. However, several concepts of the game's design are very interesting:

The tomes and grimoires (which cause -33% HP loss to the group per grimoire possessed) are mechanics that allow pushing map exploration with a risk management variable (in addition to the grimoire effect, tomes do not allow possessing a medkit or healing potion simultaneously).

The quality of chests that improves based on the level's difficulty, further improved post-game based on tomes and grimoires recovered and whether Quick Play was activated or not, is a remarkable way to encourage players (especially those who do not know each other) to immediately create team cohesion for the common interest of better equipment.

All side game modes (Chaos Wastes, Versus, and, to a lesser extent, Winds of Magic) are thought to heal the lacks and defects of the game, and it works quite well, particularly for Chaos Wastes with its curse mechanics by the Chaos Gods, the exclusive maps it offers, and the unique attributes to the mode.

Crafting is very simple, clear, and accessible to all level ranges. It allows quickly getting a handle on equipment traits and attributes and naturally provides flexibility on different builds.

Achievement: 12/25 - Achievements allow exploring the entirety of Campaign mode, from Act I to IV, but it is unfortunate that they do not involve all other maps, which are nevertheless interesting. Some challenges involve using Crafting and acquiring high-level equipment, which happens quite naturally with all other achievements and allows discovering the game's mechanics. Unfortunately, the big black spot of these achievements is the part where we must reach Lvl. 30 on all game characters, five characters in total. Except that this leveling is long, extremely long. To give you an idea: according to SteamHunters, the median completion time for 100% is about.. 160 hours. This is a considerable time that far exceeds the time needed to go through the entire game. Some techniques remain however, including the one I benefited from, notably the special events offered by the studio to obtain a x2 XP bonus to double progression, or even x3 on unique days, combined with intensive practice of a quick map (like Screaming Bell) to accumulate experience points quickly, but this task remains unpleasant. To conclude, the most difficult achievement is completing the "Skittergate" mission (Act IV, in reality) on "Legend" difficulty (the second-to-last most complicated, behind Cataclysmic), which will also get you all similar post-difficulty achievements. This last achievement is an excellent way to finish the game in style, with its landscapes and epic final battle.

Final Score: 75/100 - Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is a very good game in its horde-survival genre that deserved a bit more spotlight because it has huge potential and above all allows an introduction to the Warhammer license, so I highly recommend this game.

Fantastic game loaded with content.  Left 4 dead style 4 player mission based combat game with a focus on melee instead of guns.  I mainly play singleplayer and the bots are more than competent enough to get you through normal and hard difficulties.  Anything above that and you'll likely need some human players.  The warhammer fantasy universe is so vast and interesting, so much lore, all the factions and stories.. I can't get enough of it.  All the characters feel unique from one another with different strengths, weaknesses, unlockable skill builds, and weapon options.  

The grind for better loot has gotten harder since they updated the game, I'm not a fan of that.  Basically it's like impossible to get decent quality weapons and trinkets unless you play on super hard difficulties.  You used to unlock them based on your overall level, to where you'd slowly accumulate better and better gear that was within a certain range of your current power level.  Now the max possible gear power level you obtain is limited by whatever difficulty you play on.  If you enjoy playing on normal you're stuck unlocking nothing useful at all after like power level 200, which is basically nothing.  I found myself coming back to this game less after this update mainly because I never feel like getting all sweaty and playing with real people where you worry about screwing up their session.  I just prefer normal difficulty and hard here and there, so I've basically reached the ceiling for unlocking gear.  For all the cool stuff you have to play on the very hard difficulties just to even get like a 1% chance of unlocking red gear (the best).  I get it, the super high tier gear shouldnt just be handed out like candy.. but I thought the old system worked better.

 Still a fun game even after all these years.  Graphics look good, gameplay is fun, probably some of the best first person melee combat I've felt in a game.  You can get this dirt cheap nowadays so I'd definitely give it a shot.  They are still regularly adding updates/new levels to the game to keep you coming back.

Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is one of those co-op action games that’s always fun to come back to. The combat is fast, brutal, and satisfying, enemies swarm you in huge waves, and every weapon feels impactful. Each hero plays differently, which keeps the gameplay fresh and lets everyone find their own style.
The atmosphere is great too dark forests, ruined cities, chaotic battlefields everything fits the Warhammer vibe perfectly. The game shines the most when played with a team: once everyone understands their role, the fights become intense, coordinated, and really exciting. Progression and loot give you plenty of motivation, and the higher difficulties push you to improve.
There are occasional spikes in difficulty and missions can feel repetitive after a while, but overall the experience stays highly enjoyable. A great choice if you want brutal fantasy combat and strong co-op gameplay.

However, some gripes:

There should absolutely be a way to break from a grapple. Even if it's just VERY INCREDIBLY difficult. Like turn it into a crazy near impossible rhythm mechanic or something. It is incredibly non fun just to sit and watch yourself be hauled away and nothing to be done but hope your team mates are near by. - or on the flip side, literally had 3/4 of the team all near each other all get grappled all at the exact same time. Ending a run that literally should not have ended. (We were so stacked that we just weren't gonna die. Had so much survivability and Regen stacked, it was nuts) Game just went "ya know what? Y'all are having too much fun. Imma nab ya all at the same time" heh. 

Second, with each character having 4 "classes" or whatever they call them, it would be nice if y'all could play the same character, but a different class. Like in my group, two of us want to play victor and two of us Wana play Markus, but we Wana play different classes of that charscter. - I get it, it would mess with the banter (maybe balance?) or story a bit. Buuuuut, is that really a reason? Like, does it really matter? There are 5 characters but only 4 players, so any given time, you are down one character for banter anyhow... So if you have one duplicate character, just play a lil less voice lines? Like if you have two Markus, one Siena, and one victor, you just do voice lines that mix with those three characters and ignore the double Markus. Simple. Heck, it could even be a perk, as after you hear a voice line once, it just becomes more background noise. And after you play the campaign once, you are just here to bash monsters and power creep (I ain't end game, but that's the very obvious feel after 20 hours or so).

Games "old" now (still looks and plays great) so I am sure these changes ain't gonna get made. But they are my major gripes.

Fantastic, first-person, four-player, hack and slash with a variety of charming characters, all of which are brilliantly voiced.
Each character also has a variety of melee and range weapons, as well as having a small but impactful talent tree giving you a choice of one of three talents every five levels up to lvl 30.
There are 5 characters with three unlockable classes, and one purchasable DLC class each.

The melee weapons all have a unique light attack pattern and a unique heavy attack pattern, as well as damage values, cleave potential, and armour damage.

Base game has 4 difficulties, with a more challenging difficulty, being unlockable after purchasing a DLC.
Recruit - Veteran - Champion - Legend - Cataclysm (DLC difficulty)

Base game has multiple maps in 'campaign' mode, and Chaos Wastes - a randomly generated mode, with rogue-lite systems like per-run upgrades, and buffs.

If you like Left4Dead, or other similar games in which you must move through a level from point A to point B, all while fighting off endless waves of enemies, it is very likely you'll enjoy this game.

The community is dope too. So many friendly players happy to show newbies the ropes, and collectable locations.

TL;DR: Vermintide 2 is a solid co-op game with distinct playstyles for each career, plenty of missions, and its best experience at max level and high difficulty, especially with friends. If you liked Vermintide, Darktide is also worth trying since it is more polished and has a stronger endgame.

It builds well on what the first game offered. Each character has multiple careers with different playstyles, giving you several ways to approach the same fights. The game also includes a good number of missions with varied layouts, which helps keep the experience fresh.

The game really opens up at max level and on the tougher difficulties. That is where your builds, weapons, and team coordination show their value, and the runs feel more strategic. Vermintide 2 can be played solo, but it works much better with friends since communication and teamwork make the missions smoother.

If you enjoyed the first Vermintide, you should also consider trying Darktide, which follows the same formula, is more polished, and offers more structured endgame content. Overall, Vermintide 2 is a consistent and enjoyable co-op experience.

TLDR: The game is garbage. Even getting this slop for free is too expensive. 

The game had the potential to be an awesome co-op action game, but instead it feels like an exercise in frustration. The core issue is the wildly inconsistent difficulty. Far too often the game throws you into situations where you simply don’t have the tools, positioning, or resources to handle what it demands. Deaths frequently feel cheap rather than deserved, and losses rarely teach you anything except that the difficulty spikes can be completely arbitrary.

The combat system and progression loop are supposed to be the game’s draw, but when encounters swing from trivial to overwhelming without warning, the experience becomes more punishing than fun. Instead of feeling challenged, you feel blindsided.

On the visual side, character design is also oddly lackluster. Several of the female characters in particular suffer from inconsistent or unappealing design choices that don’t match the tone or quality the game aspires to. Not a very big surprise though considering it´s made by wester developers. 

Overall, Vermintide 2 struggles to deliver a satisfying gameplay experience. If you’re hoping for a fair challenge, cohesive design, or a sense of earned accomplishment, look elsewhere.
